question.para: Why isn't some package manager in the book?

answer.para: Package management - beyond that provided by tarballs and makefiles - is beyond the scope of the book. If nothing else does, the number of different "solutions" should hint at some of the reasons.

Here are a few of the options:
No package management is really necessary. Unless it is desirable to monitor package file placement minutely, any package large enough to warrent removal for disk space reasons can be installed in /opt as detailed by the FHS (perhaps in /opt/foo-x.x with a link from /opt/foo), and new releases can usually be installed over the old, although major upgrades and libraries are generally best done by rebuilding the system from the bottom up.
RPM, the Redhat Package Manager, is used by a number of distributions. It is available from , and there is an RPM Hint to help with installation at .
There is an RPM based LFS at
There are several implementations of symlink style package management:
Epkg is available from .
Graft is available from .
GNU Stow is available from .
Depot is available from .
And several more are listed in the Graft documentation at .
The NetBSD package manager, pkgsrc, is available on other systems including Linux. It is at .
Originally based on a script written by LFS' own Gerard Beekmans, install-log records a list of files installed by a package as the package is installed. It is available from .
Gerard has since made additions to his script. It is available from and .
CheckInstall attempts log system calls made by "make install". It is available from .
pkgutils, used by the CRUX distribution, is available from .
More information about these systems and information about other interesting systems is at .
If you have an addition to the list, please do email its name, URL, and other information, to the FAQ maintainer or an apropriate LFS mailing list so it can be added here.
